item.description:
The divergent paths of three forty-something siblings collide when their mother, heiress to her uncle's exceptional 19th century art collection, dies suddenly. Left to come to terms with themselves and their differences, Adrienne (Juliette Binoche), a successful New York designer, Frederic (Charles Berling), an economist and university professor in Paris, and Jérémie (Jérémie Renier), a dynamic businessman in China, confront the end of childhood, their shared memories, background and unique vision of the future. Written and directed by Olivier Assayas (Clean, Demonlover).

From the New York Times Critic's Pick Review:

This extraordinary film, which, in spite of its modest scale, tactful manner and potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication. . .while Mr. Assayas’s filmmaking techniques are identifiably of the moment — and his sensibility is as thoroughly French as the long, painstakingly prepared family meals that punctuate “Summer Hours” — the assurance and aesthetic poise of the film make it quietly ravishing.

Summer Hours

Following the film, we'll attempt to get a table at The Friendly Toast, opening today in Kendall Square (thanks to Tom Green for 'discovering' them setting up in place of the (twice) defunct chinese restaurant). Those who've been to the Telluride By the Sea Film Festival in Portsmouth, New Hampshire are familiar with the original Friendly Toast, a family friendly restaurant. Great food and a great place for a group discussion - provided there is space for us on a Saturday night!

Time approximate. Specific start time to be posted later in the week.
